facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 432 of 1957 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 432 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated September 27, 1955 of Patna High Court in Civil Revision No. 24 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 27, 1955, of the Patna High Court in Civil Revision No. 24 of 1954.

facts.text: Appellant was plaintiff in title suit in Court of Subordinate Judge 11, Gaya.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant who was plaintiff in a title suit in the Court of the Subordinate Judge 11, Gaya, has appealed against the dismissal of his suit by the High Court at Patna,

facts.text: Plaintiff asked for declaration that he was nominated Mahant of Moghal Juan Sangat by Guru Mahanth Gulab Das by registered deed dated October 21, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: In the suit he had asked for a declaration that he was nominated Mahant of Moghal Juan Sangat by his Guru, Mahanth Gulab Das, by a registered deed dated October 21, 1944, and that he had thus the right to manage the Sangat and other off-shoots thereof.

facts.text: Suit dismissed by trial Judge on May 31, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: His suit was dismissed by the trial Judge on May 31, 1947.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: He then appealed to the High Court at Patna,

facts.text: High Court appeal decided in appellant's favour on November 26, 1951 on condition of paying court fee on amended relief of possession.

anchor.surface_text: and on November 26, 1951, the appeal was decided in his favour on condition that he paid court fee on the amended relief of possession of properties involved in the suit,

facts.text: Case sent to Court of First Instance for determining value of properties and fixing court fee.

anchor.surface_text: for which purpose the case was sent to the Court of First Instance for determining the value of the properties and for fixed the amount of court fee to be paid.

facts.text: V. Ramaswami, J. and C. P. Sinha, J. held valuation Rs. 12,178-4-0 and ad valorem court fee payable.

anchor.surface_text: V. Ramaswami, J. and C. P. Sinha, J.  as they then were  held that the valuation for the purpose of the suit was Rs. 12,178-4-0, and that ad valorem court fee was payable on it.

facts.text: High Court directed office to calculate court fee and communicate to counsel for plaintiff-appellant, granting three months time from date counsel informed.

anchor.surface_text: They, therefore, made a direction as follows The High Court office will calculate the amount of court fee payable on the valuation we have given and communicate to the counsel for plaintiff-appellant what is the amount of the court-fee he has got to pay both on the plaint and on the memorandum of appeal. We grant the plaintiff three months time to pay the court-fee for the Trial Court and also for the High Court.

facts.text: High Court office gave intimation on April 8, 1954 that deficit court fee payable was Rs. 1,987-8-0.

anchor.surface_text: The office of the High Court gave intimation on April 8, 1954, that the deficit court fee payable was Rs. 1,987-8-0.

facts.text: Time to pay expired on July 8, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The time was to expire on July 8, 1954 but the appellant was not able to find the money.

facts.text: Appellant's advocate asked case to be mentioned before Vacation Judge on July 8, 1954 for extension.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the appellants advocate in the High Court asked the case to be mentioned before the Vacation Judge on July 8, 1954, so that a request for extension of time could be made.

facts.text: No Division Bench sitting on July 8, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: No Division Bench, however, was sitting on that date,

facts.text: Appellant filed application on July 8, 1954 requesting to pay Rs. 1,400 immediately and balance within a month.

anchor.surface_text: and the appellant filed an application on July 8, 1954, requesting that he be allowed to pay Rs. 1,400 immediately, and the balance, within a month thereafter.

facts.text: Application placed before Division Bench of Ramaswami and Ahmad, JJ. who dismissed it stating appeal stood dismissed per order dated 30th March, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: This application was placed before a Division Bench consisting of Ramaswami and Ahmad, JJ., when the following order was passed This application for extension of time must be dismissed. By virtue of the order of the Bench dated the 30th March, 1954, the appeal has already stood dismissed as the amount was not paid within the time given.

facts.text: Appellant moved application under s. 151 rejected by Imam, C.J. and Narayan, J. on September 2, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved an application under s. 151, which was rejected by Imam, C.J. and Narayan, J., on September 2, 1954.

facts.text: Imam C.J. and Narayan J. suggested proper remedy was review.

anchor.surface_text: They, however, felt that the proper remedy was review.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition under s. 151 read with O. 47, R. 1 CPC stating reasons unable to pay: seriously ill, attempted loan but grain market slumped.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then filed another petition under s. 151, read with 0. 47, R. 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure, setting out the reasons why he was unable to find the money. He stated that he was seriously ill, and though he had attempted to raise a loan, he was unable to get sufficient money, as the grain market had slumped suddenly, and people were unable to advance money.

facts.text: Review application offered to pay deficit court fee within further time as High Court might fix.

anchor.surface_text: He offered to pay the deficit court fee within such further time as the High Court might fix.

facts.text: Review application heard on September 27, 1955 by Ramaswami and Sinha, JJ. and dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: This application for review was heard on September 27, 1955, by Ramaswami and Sinha, JJ. They first considered it from the viewpoint of 0. 47, R. 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure, and held that the application did not fall within the Order.

facts.text: High Court rejected arguments for extension under s. 148 or 149 CPC as applicable only before final disposal.

anchor.surface_text: The argument of counsel that time could have been extended under s. 148 or s. 149 of the Code of Civil Procedure was also not accepted. The learned Judges held that these sections applied only to cases which were not finally disposed of, and that time under them could be extended only before the final order was actually made.

facts.text: Request under inherent powers rejected for same reason.

anchor.surface_text: The request to extend the time under the inherent powers of the Court was also rejected for the same reason.

facts.text: Ramaswami J. expressed considerable sympathy for plaintiff but dismissed petition without costs.

anchor.surface_text: Ramaswami, J., concluded his order by saying I have considerable sympathy towards the plaintiff petitioner who has placed himself in an unfortunate position, but we must be careful not to allow our sympathy to affect our judgment.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court by K. K. Banerji and R. K. Chaudhary, JJ.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved the High Court for a certificate, and the case was heard by K. K. Banerji and R. K. Chaudhary, JJ. Though the decree was one of affirmance, the learned Judges fortunately found it possible to grant a certificate,

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J. on February 7, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. February 7. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside order of July 13, 1954 and subsequent orders.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, set aside the order of July 13, 1954, and the orders made subsequently.

facts.text: Supreme Court found sufficient cause made out for extension of time based on application and affidavit.

anchor.surface_text: We have perused the application and the affidavit, and we are satisfied that sufficient cause had been made out for extension of time.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted appellant two months time from February 7, 1961 for payment of deficit court fee.

anchor.surface_text: We, accordingly, set aside the dismissal of the appeal and the suit, and grant the appellant two months time from today for payment of the deficit court fee.

facts.text: Respondent did not appear in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: C. Prasad, for the appellant. The respondent did not appear.

facts.text: Application for extension filed before time fixed had run out.

anchor.surface_text: The application for extension of time was made before the time fixed by the High Court for payment of deficit court fee had actually run out.

holdings.text: Section 148 of the Code, in terms, allows extension of time, even if the original period fixed has expired, and s. 149 is equally liberal. A fortiori, those sections could be invoked by the applicant, when the time had not actually expired.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of ss. 148 and 149 CPC permits enlargement of time post-expiry of fixed period, with greater force when time has not expired.

holdings.text: Such procedural orders, though peremptory (conditional decrees apart) are, in essence, in terrorem, so that dilatory litigants might put themselves in order and avoid delay. They do not, however, completely estop a Court from taking note of events and circumstances which happen within the time fixed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Peremptory procedural orders deter delay but courts retain power to consider intervening events and extend time, following precedents like Lachmi Narain Marwari v. Balmakund Marwari.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the High Court was in error on both the occasions. Time should have been extended on July 13, 1954, if sufficient cause was made out and again, when the petitions were made for the exercise of the inherent powers.
